{{Multiple issues| {{medical citations needed|date=December 2014}} {{POV|date=May 2016}} }} [[File:Man in black tights.jpg|thumb|A man in tights|327x327px]]
'''Compression garments''' are pieces of clothing that fit tightly around the skin. In medical contexts, compression garments provide support for people who have to stand for long periods or have poor [[Circulatory system|circulation]]. These come in varying degrees of compression, and higher degree compression sleeves, such as sleeves that provide compression of 20–30 mmHg or higher, typically require a doctor's prescription.<ref>{{Cite web|year = 2016 |url = http://www.seattlecca.org/shine/oncology-products/compression-garments/about-compression-sleeves-and-garment#3 |title = Seattle Cancer Care Alliance| publisher = seattlecca.org | accessdate = 2016-12-12}}</ref> Compression garments worn on the legs can help prevent [[deep vein thrombosis]] and reduce swelling, especially while traveling.
In sports, form-fitting compression sportswear, usually made of [[spandex]], is commonly worn by athletes and in exercise to prevent [[Chafing (skin)|chafing]] and [[rash]]es.
==Maternity== A '''bellyband''', '''wrap''', or '''abdominal binder''' is a compression garment which resembles a [[tubetop]] worn over the abdomen of expectant mothers.<ref>{{citation |last=Curtis |first=Glade B. |last2=Schuler |first2=Judith |display-authors=1 |ref={{harvid|Curtis & al.}} |p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=4z__CwAAQBAJ&pg=PA414 414] |title=Your Pregnancy: Week by Week, ''8th ed.'' |date=2016 |publisher=Da Capo Press }}.</ref> Belly wraps are also very commonly worn postpartum. Belly wraps are typically prescribed for abdominal support, making it easier for people with back pain to perform day to day tasks, as well as to help mothers with their posture and potential back problems post delivery.
==Stockings== {{main|Compression stockings}} Compression stockings are specialized hosiery designed to help prevent the occurrence of and guard against further progression of various medical disorders.
80 years ago, a pair of lady's stockings began the "age of synthetics." <ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smithsonian-institution/how-75-years-ago-nylon-stockings-changed-world-180955219/|title=How 75 Years Ago Nylon Stockings Changed the World|last=Cutlip|first=Kimbra|work=Smithsonian|access-date=2017-05-27|language=en}}</ref> The National Museum of American History holds the experimental stockings that were created in 1937 to test the viability of the first man-made fiber that was created entirely in a lab.<ref name=":1" /> Nylon was thought to have the strength of steel and the sheerness of cobwebs. These stockings became a very hot commodity when they were first released for public purchase. Their demand was so high that four million pairs sold in the first four days.<ref name=":1" /> Nylon's impact on fashion was immediate, but the invention sparked a revolution. Nylon's original name was fiber-66.<ref name=":1" />
Stockings became so important to a woman's image that, during World War II, when stockings were not being sold because all nylon was diverted to military use, women began painting their legs with makeup, trying to create the image of nylon stockings.<ref name=":1" />
==Sportswear== [[File:Chiara Simionato in action (08-12-2007) 3.jpg|thumb|A speedskater in a bodysuit]] [[File:Grand Slam Moscow 2012, Set 2 - 022.jpg|thumb|A beach volleyball player in tights]] Compression sportswear is usually worn by athletes, including shirts, shorts, [[tights]], sleeves, socks, or underwear. They are [[form-fitting garment]]s often made from a [[spandex]]-type material.
One small study of compression shorts found no change in sprint time, but found some gait changes that might reduce injuries.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/0264041031000101971 |vauthors=Doan BK, Kwon YH, Newton RU |title=Evaluation of a lower-body compression garment |journal=J Sports Sci |volume=21 |issue=8 |pages=601–10 |date=Aug 2003 |pmid=12875311 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> Another study of calf sleeves found no change in sprint times and gait; larger reviews have found no evidence that compression garments can improve athletic performance beyond the [[placebo effect]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.npr.org/2015/04/11/398929121/compression-clothes-advantage-could-be-placebo-effect | title=Compression Clothes' Advantage Could be Placebo Effect}}</ref>
Through testing repeat-sprint and throwing performance in cricket players, one study found that there was a significant difference by way of higher mean skin temperature, lower 24-hour post exercise [[Creatine kinase|CK]] values and lower 24-hour post exercise ratings of muscle soreness when wearing compression garments. However, the study failed to find any significant difference in sprint performance, throwing performance, heart rate, or various blood tests.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=17341589 |year=2007 |author1=Duffield |first2=M |last3=Edge |title=Comparison of three types of full-body compression garments on throwing and repeat-sprint performance in cricket players |volume=41 |issue=7 |pages=409–14; discussion 414 |doi=10.1136/bjsm.2006.033753 |journal=British Journal of Sports Medicine |first3=J.|last2=Portus |pmc=2465357}}</ref>
In materials testing, the compressive garment provided increased flexion and extension, which could help reduce hamstring injuries. They also reduced impact by 27% compared to American football pants alone.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=12875311 |year=2003 |author1=Doan |first2=YH |last3=Newton |first3=RU |last4=Shim |first4=J |last5=Popper |first5=EM |last6=Rogers |first6=RA |last7=Bolt |first7=LR |last8=Robertson |first8=M |last9=Kraemer |first9=WJ |title=Evaluation of a lower-body compression garment |volume=21 |issue=8 |pages=601–10 |journal=Journal of Sports Sciences |doi=10.1080/0264041031000101971|last2=Kwon }}</ref> Studies have shown that compressive garments can improve long term vertical jump height.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://journals.lww.com/nsca-jscr/Abstract/1996/08000/Influence_of_Compression_Garments_on_Vertical_Jump.9.aspx|title=Influence of Compression Garments on Vertical Jump Performan... : The Journal of Strength & Conditioning Research|work=LWW|access-date=2017-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref>
Depending on the material used, compression garments can be designed to keep athletes cool or warm depending on the requirements of the sport. This is why you will see both athletes in the winter and summer olympics wearing similar looking compression outfits. For example, speedskaters can wear compression bodysuits in the cold rink, while beach volleyball players can wear a similar-looking piece made out of a more breathable, lightweight blend. Both athletes will use moisture wicking materials such as nylon and spandex to keep them lightweight, while cotton would retain moisture and weigh them down in action. In addition, speed skaters take advantage of the aerodynamic advantage they can get from wearing a skintight suit, while a beach volleyball player has the added benefit of SPF 50+ garments to keep them protected on a sunny day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.womenshealthandfitness.com.au/fitness/workouts/268-compressed-for-success|title=The compression clothing phenomenon - Women's Health & Fitness|website=www.womenshealthandfitness.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-05-30}}</ref> The athletes pictured show the diverse range of benefits that make compression garments so popular in a wide range of sports and designs.
Other purported benefits of compression sportswear are: *Keeping the muscles warm to prevent muscle strain.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.berkeleywellness.com/fitness/active-lifestyle/article/skinny-compression-shorts|title=Benefits of Wearing Compression Shorts|website=@berkeleywellness|access-date=2017-05-15}}</ref> *Wicking sweat away from the body to prevent chafing and rashes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.primecompression.com/the-5-most-important-compression-shorts-benefits/|title=5 Reasons Why You Should Wear Compression Shorts|website=Prime Compression|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-15}}</ref> *Helping relieve pain from muscle stiffness and soreness.<ref name="The Compression Clothing Craze">{{Cite news|url=http://www.mensjournal.com/gear/sports/the-compression-sportswear-craze-20131108|title=The Compression Clothing Craze|work=Men's Journal|access-date=2017-05-15}}</ref>[[File:WrestlingUSAF Flag.jpg|thumb|Wrestlers wear compressing, elastic clothing.]] *Reducing the time taken for muscles to repair themselves.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=11411623 |year=2001 |last1=Kraemer |first1=WJ |last2=Bush |last3=Wickham |last4=Denegar |last5=Gómez |last6=Gotshalk |last7=Duncan |last8=Volek |last9=Putukian |title=Influence of compression therapy on symptoms following soft tissue injury from maximal eccentric exercise |volume=31 |issue=6 |pages=282–90 |journal=The Journal of Orthopaedic and Sports Physical Therapy |first2=JA |first3=RB |first4=CR |first5=AL |first6=LA |first7=ND |first8=JS |first9=M|last10=Sebastianelli |first10=W. J. |display-authors=8 |doi=10.2519/jospt.2001.31.6.282 }}</ref> *When the right amount of compression is used (will vary depending on body area, typically in the range of 10 to 25 mmHg), improving venous return and oxygenation to working muscles.<ref name="The Compression Clothing Craze"/> *Stabilizing joints.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}
===Shorts and tights=== Compression shorts and tights are [[underwear|undergarments]] usually worn by athletes. They are [[form-fitting garment]]s and when worn, cover the athlete's waist to mid or lower thigh, similar to [[cycling shorts]]. [[File:Hurdler.jpg|thumb|Hurdler in full compression uniform]] More recently, [[jockstrap]]s have declined in popularity with young male athletes, and garments such as compression shorts have seen an increase in popularity, arguably because of their comparable function and less embarrassing looks. Many are available with a [[Jockstrap#Protective cup|cup pocket]], a sewn-in pocket that can hold a protective cup. It is arguable that compression shorts do not keep cups in the proper position, tight to the body and not moving, as a jockstrap can. Some players wear the compression shorts over the traditional jockstrap.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2123007/|title=Where have all the jockstraps gone?|work=Slate Magazine (2005-07-22)|date=2005-07-22}}</ref>
Compression shorts are also popular among female athletes, especially among those who wear [[skirts]] or [[kilts]] during games. In those situations, athletes wear compression shorts under the skirt so if they fall over and their skirts ride up, their underwear will not be exposed. This is seen particularly in [[women's lacrosse]] and [[field hockey]] (both being limited contact sports in which players often wear skirts). In this situation, compression shorts are colloquially identified as [[spandex]] shorts. Women also wear compression shorts in tennis, where, most recently, compression shorts have been produced with ball pockets for convenience.
=== Post-workout benefit === Compression garments have been shown to help athletes during the active recovery process. Research shows that following a high intensity treadmill workout, compression garments helped to decrease the heart rate and lactic acid buildup in athletes.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lovell|first=Dale I.|last2=Mason|first2=Dale G.|last3=Delphinus|first3=Elias M.|last4=McLellan|first4=Christopher P.|date=2011-12-01|title=Do compression garments enhance the active recovery process after high-intensity running?|journal=Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research|volume=25|issue=12|pages=3264–3268|doi=10.1519/JSC.0b013e31821764f8|issn=1533-4287|pmid=22082795|citeseerx=10.1.1.671.5841}}</ref> According to a study by Duffield R. and M. Portis, although there were few observed changes during their event, cricket players wearing compression garments showed fewer blood markers of muscle damage and reported less soreness during the 24-hour post-workout period.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Duffield|first=Rob|last2=Portus|first2=Marc|date=2007-07-01|title=Comparison of three types of full-body compression garments on throwing and repeat-sprint performance in cricket players|journal=British Journal of Sports Medicine|volume=41|issue=7|pages=409–414; discussion 414|doi=10.1136/bjsm.2006.033753|issn=1473-0480|pmc=2465357|pmid=17341589}}</ref> Other studies have supported the idea that compression garments are effective in reducing post-workout declines in jump height, minimizing strength loss, decreasing swelling, and easing muscle soreness after competition.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.active.com/running/articles/is-compression-gear-really-effective?page=3|title=Is Compression Gear Really Effective?|date=2012-12-11|work=ACTIVE.com|access-date=2017-05-30}}</ref>

He competes mainly in the [[ITF Men's Circuit]] and [[ATP Challenger Tour]]. He has won two ATP Challenger Tour singles titles. In addition, he has won five singles titles and three doubles titles in the ITF Men's Circuit. . ==Career== Lestienne reached his first career ATP World Tour singles main draw (where he lost in the first round to [[Pablo Carreño Busta]]) at the [[2015 Estoril Open – Singles|2015 Estoril Open]] after winning two singles qualifying matches. ===Betting scandal=== In September 2016 Lestienne was suspended for seven months and fined $10,000 by the [[International Tennis Federation]] for betting on tennis matches. The [[Tennis Integrity Unit]] (TIU) in cooperation with French online gambling regulator ARJEL found that Lestienne had bet on 220 tennis matches between February 2012 and June 2015. None of these matches were his own. Half of the ban is suspended and his fine will be halved if he cooperates with the TIU.{{cite web|title=Tour player Constant Lestienne banned for seven months after betting on tennis RF – {{convert|335|ft|m}} }} '''Coolray Field ''' (formerly known as '''Gwinnett Stadium''') is a 10,427-seat [[Minor league baseball|minor league]] [[baseball park]] in unincorporated [[Gwinnett County, Georgia]] (with a mailing address in [[Lawrenceville, Georgia|Lawrenceville]]). It is the home field of the [[Gwinnett Stripers]], the [[Triple-A (baseball)|Triple-A]] [[Farm team#Baseball|affiliate]] of the [[Atlanta Braves]], and [[Atlanta United 2]], the [[United Soccer League]] affiliate of [[Atlanta United FC]]. ==History== Coolray Field hosted its first regular season baseball game on April 17, 2009, a 7–4 [[Gwinnett Braves]] loss to the [[Norfolk Tides]].{{cite news |title=G-Braves' Loss Can't Ruin New Team's Home Opener|first=Ben|last=Beitzel|url=http://www.gwinnettdailypost.com/news/2009/apr/18/g-braves039-loss-can039t-ruin-new-team039s-home/|newspaper=[[Gwinnett Daily Post]]|date=April 18, 2009|accessdate=March 9, 2014}} The stadium site is located approximately two miles (3 km) east of the [[Mall of Georgia]] along [[Georgia State Route 20|Georgia 20]], between [[Interstate 85 (Georgia)|Interstate 85]] and [[Georgia 316]]. The {{convert|44|acre|ha|adj=on}} site was previously [[arable land|farmland]] and [[forest]]. An additional {{convert|73|acre|km2}} of mostly forest around it became a [[mixed-use]] project, after a February 2009 [[rezoning]] by the Gwinnett County Commission.{{cite news |title=BOC Approves Rezoning Near Stadium|first=Jamie|last=Ward|url=http://www.gwinnettdailypost.com/news/2009/feb/04/boc-approves-rezoning-near-stadium/|newspaper=[[Gwinnett Daily Post]]|date=February 4, 2009|accessdate=March 9, 2014}} [[Naming rights]] are held by Coolray, an air conditioning and plumbing company based in nearby [[Marietta, Georgia|Marietta]]. The stadium construction and maintenance is being paid by the taxpayer-funded Gwinnett County government, but the Stripers will keep most of the [[revenue]] from ticket and concession stand sales. The [[municipal bond]]s used to pay for the stadium run for 30 years (until 2038), but the Stripers have an option to back out of the [[contract]] after only half of that time (in 2023), if the county does not maintain the facility at an acceptable level. This would leave county taxpayers responsible for the remainder.{{cite news |title=Contract Bringing Braves AAA Farm Team to Gwinnett Signed Tuesday|first=Arielle|last=Kass|url=http://www.gwinnettdailypost.com/news/2008/apr/02/contract-bringing-braves-aaa-farm-team-to/|newspaper=[[Gwinnett Daily Post]]|date=April 2, 2008|accessdate=March 9, 2014}} After the first season, it was revealed that [[parking]] revenue was a fraction (about 15%) of what was expected.{{cite news |title=Gwinnett Braves Parking Revenue Falls Short of County Expectations|first=Patrick|last=Fox|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/gwinnett/gwinnett-braves-parking-revenue-188884.html|newspaper=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|date=November 6, 2009|accessdate=November 6, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091108172929/http://www.ajc.com/news/gwinnett/gwinnett-braves-parking-revenue-188884.html|archivedate=November 8, 2009|deadurl=yes}} The Gwinnett Braves (renamed to the Stripers in 2017) moved to the stadium in 2009 when the [[Atlanta Braves]] moved their affiliate, the [[Richmond Braves]], after 43 seasons (1966–2008) in [[Richmond, Virginia]]. They are located 35 miles northeast of their parent club's stadium, [[SunTrust Park]] in unincorporated [[Cobb County]]—the second-shortest distance between a Triple-A team and its major league parent (behind only the [[Pacific Coast League]]'s [[Tacoma Rainiers]], based 26 miles south of Seattle). They have held this distinction since moving to Gwinnett County; the Braves played at [[Turner Field]] in Atlanta at the time. ==Features== Coolray Field features 19 luxury suites, a 30-foot-by-40-foot video board in right-center field, a 6-foot-by-42-foot LED board along the left-field wall and chairback seating complete with cupholders.{{cite web |title=2012 Gwinnett Braves Digital Media Guide|url=http://www.milb.com/documents/2012/04/05/27948772/1/2012_Gwinnett_Braves_Digital_Media_Guide.pdf|publisher=[[Gwinnett Braves]]|date=April 5, 2012|accessdate=April 29, 2012}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Portal|Atlanta}} * [http://www.gwinnettbraves.com/stadium. Coolray Field] * [http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/gwinnett/stories/2008/03/01/gwinnettdeal_0302.html ''AJC'' article] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100513011216/http://corinthhills.org/gwinnett/gwinnett-braves-inaugural-season-attendance/ Inaugural season attendance article] * [http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2011/Lawrenceville/Lawrenceville.htm Coolray Field Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] {{IL Ballparks}} {{United Soccer League Venues}} [[Category:Sports venues in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Gwinnett County, Georgia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:2009 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:USL Championship stadiums]] [[Category:Gwinnett Stripers]]

The team was founded by [[Gediz University]] in 2010. Their home arena is Gediz Üniversitesi Sports Hall with a capacity of 250 seats. The team sponsored by Orkide which is an liquid oil company in [[Turkey]]. == External links == * [http://gedizbasket.com/ Gediz Üniversitesi Basketbol Kulübü], Official Website * [http://basketball.eurobasket.com/team/Turkey/Orkide_Gediz_Univeristesi/19371 Eurobasket.com Page] * [https://www.facebook.com/gedizbasket Official Facebook Page] * [https://twitter.com/gediz_basket Official Twitter Account] * [https://instagram.com/gedizbasket Instagram Account] {{DEFAULTSORT:Gediz Universitesi S.K.}} [[Category:Basketball teams in Turkey]] [[Category:Basketball teams established in 2010]] [[Category:Sport in Izmir]] {{Turkey-basketball-team-stub}}

Národní Hokejová Liga|Czech 1st National Hockey League]], the second-highest league in the country. Slavia played in the [[Czech Extraliga|Extraliga]] from 1994 until 2015, winning the national championship in 2003 and 2008. The club plays its home games at Zimní stadion Eden in [[Prague]]. From 2004 until 2015, it played at [[O2 Arena (Prague)|O2 Arena]]. The team played in the [[2008–09 Champions Hockey League|2008–09 season]] of the [[Champions Hockey League]]. 18,000 | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Oman First Division League]] | season = [[2014–15 Oman First Division League|2014–15]] | position = '''1st''' (Winners) | pattern_la1 = |pattern_b1=_thinwhitesides|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1 = FF0000|body1=FF0000|rightarm1=FF0000|shorts1=000000|socks1=FF0000 | pattern_la2 = |pattern_b2=_thinredsides|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2 = FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=000000|socks2=FFFFFF }} '''Muscat Club''' ({{Lang-ar|نادي مسقط}}; also known locally as ''Faris Al-A'asima'', or "Knight of the Capital", or just plainly as '''Muscat''') is an [[Football clubs of Oman|Omani sports club]] based in [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]], [[Oman]].{{cite web | url = http://www.national-football-teams.com/club/2968/2013_1/Muscat_Club.html | title = Muscat Club | publisher = national-football-teams.com}} The club is currently playing in the [[First Division League]] of [[Oman Football Association]]. Their home ground is [[Sultan Qaboos Sports Complex]], but they also recognize the older [[Royal Oman Police Stadium]] as their home ground. Both stadiums are government owned, but Muscat Club also own their own personal stadium and sports equipments, as well as their own training facilities. ==Being a multisport club== Although being mainly known for their football, Muscat Club like many other clubs in Oman, have not only football in their list, but also [[field hockey|hockey]], [[volleyball]], [[Team handball|handball]], [[basketball]], [[badminton]] and [[squash (sport)|squash]]. They also have a youth football team competing in the Omani Youth league. ==Colors, kit providers and sponsors== Like the [[Oman national football team]], Muscat Club have also long-chosen [[red]] or [[white]] (with black shorts) (Away) as the colors to represent them, varying themselves from neighbors [[Bowsher Club]] ([[Blue]]) and [[Oman Club]] ([[Red]]) [[Kit (association football)|kit]]s. They have also had many different sponsors over the years. ==Honours and achievements== ===National titles=== *'''[[Omani League]]''' (3): :*Winners [[1977-78 Omani League|1977-78]], [[2002-03 Omani League|2002-03]], [[2005-06 Omani League|2005-06]] :*Runners-up [[2003–04 Omani League|2003–04]] *'''[[Oman First Division League]]''' (1): :*Winners [[2014–15 Oman First Division League|2014-15]] *'''[[Sultan Qaboos Cup]]''' (1): :*Winners [[2003 Sultan Qaboos Cup|2003]] (As Ruwi) :*Runners up [[2004 Sultan Qaboos Cup|2004]], [[2007 Sultan Qaboos Cup|2007]] *'''[[Oman Super Cup]]''' (2): :*Winners 2004, 2005 ==Club performance-International Competitions== ===AFC competitions=== *'''[[AFC Cup]]''' : 1 appearance :*[[2007 AFC Cup|2007]] : Group Stage ===UAFA competitions=== *'''[[Gulf Club Champions Cup]]''': 3 appearances :*[[2005 Gulf Club Champions Cup|2005]] : 3rd Position :*[[2006 Gulf Club Champions Cup|2006]] : Group Stage :*[[2007 Gulf Club Champions Cup|2007]] : Group Stage ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/oman/muscat/6073/ Muscat Club Profile at Soccerway.com] *[http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?team=1320 Muscat Club Profile at Goalzz.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Muscat Club}} [[Category:Year of establishment missing]] [[Category:Football clubs in Oman]] [[Category:Omani League]] [[Category:Sports clubs in Muscat, Oman]] [[Category:Omani sport stubs]] [[Category:Asian football club stubs]] {{Oman-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = New ASU Stadium | image = The New ASU Stadium.JPG | image_size = 225px | caption = New ASU Stadium | location = [[Montgomery, Alabama]] | coordinates = {{coord|32|21|50|N|86|17|26|W|region:US-AL_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = February 4, 2011{{cite news |title=ASU Football Stadium Groundbreaking, Baseball Complex Ribbon Cutting Friday|first=Ben|last=Flanagan|url=http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2011/02/asu_football_stadium_groundbre.html|newspaper=Alabama Live LLC.|date=February 3, 2011|accessdate=July 8, 2012}} | opened = November 22, 2012{{cite news |title=ASU 'Clock and Block' Party to Count Down Days Until Stadium Play|first=Christine|last=Kneidinger Hull|url=http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2011/09/asu_clock_and_block_party_to_c.html|work=Alabama Live LLC.|date=September 14, 2011|accessdate=July 8, 2012}} | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Alabama State University]] | operator = [[Alabama State University]] | surface = [[AstroTurf]]{{cite web|title=Alabama State to debut new AstroTurf field on Thanksgiving Day|url=http://astroturfusa.blogspot.com/2012/11/alabama-state-to-debut-new-astroturf.html|publisher=AstroTurf USA|accessdate=February 27, 2018|date=November 20, 2012}} | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]62 million | architect = Brown Chambless Architects{{cite news |title=Alabama St. Sees New $50M Stadium As First Step to FBS Status|first=Don|last=Muret|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2011/10/03/Facilities/Breaking-Ground.aspx|work=[[Advance Publications|SportsBusiness Journal]]|date=October 3, 2011|accessdate=July 8, 2012}}
Convergence Design | structural engineer = Blackburn Daniels O'Barr{{cite web |title=Engineering Projects|url=http://www.blackburneng.com/projects.php#athletic-projects|work=Blackburn Daniels O'Barr|accessdate=July 8, 2012}} | services engineer = CRS Engineering, Inc.{{cite web |title=ASU Football Stadium|url=http://www.aecci.com/currentprojects/asu_football/asu_football.htm|work=Auburn Electrical Construction Co., Inc.|accessdate=July 8, 2012}} | project_manager = TCU Consulting Services{{cite web|title=Clients|url=http://www.tcuconsulting.com/Clients.aspx|work=TCU Consulting Services|accessdate=July 8, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208094034/http://tcuconsulting.com/Clients.aspx|archivedate=December 8, 2013|df=}} | general_contractor = Rabren General Contractors, Inc.{{cite web |title=Pulse|url=http://enr.construction.com/resources/pulse/2012/0130-pulse.asp|work=[[Engineering News-Record]]|date=January 28, 2012|accessdate=July 8, 2012}} | former_names = | tenants = [[Alabama State Hornets football|Alabama State Hornets]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (2012–present) | seating_capacity = 26,500 | dimensions = }} The '''New ASU Stadium''' on the campus of [[Alabama State University]] in [[Montgomery, Alabama|Montgomery]], [[Alabama]] is a 26,500-seat stadium that replaces the [[Cramton Bowl]] as the host venue for the [[Alabama State Hornets football]] team. The first game in the New ASU Stadium was the 89th Turkey Day Classic on November 22, 2012 in which the Hornets hosted the [[Tuskegee Golden Tigers football|Tuskegee Golden Tigers]]. The game was a sell-out and was televised nationally on [[ESPNU]]. The Hornets lost the first ever game in their new stadium 27-25 due to a late two-point conversion by Tuskegee. The stadium's current capacity sits at 26,500 but the project was designed to allow for future expansion that can expand the capacity to 55,000.{{cite web |title=$62 million Alabama State stadium sets stage for growth across Montgomery|url=http://blog.al.com/montgomery/2012/11/new_asu_hornets_stadium_sets_s.html|work=AL.com|date=November 21, 2012|accessdate=June 11, 2013}} ==Other uses== The stadium also holds a restaurant and retail space which welcome visitors to the stadium and area 365 days a year.{{cite web|title=NewASUStadium.com: About Us|url=http://www.newasustadium.com/about.php|work=NewASUStadium.com|date=|accessdate=June 11, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012020453/http://www.newasustadium.com/about.php|archivedate=October 12, 2013|df=}} The stadium itself will be used year-round with other events such as concerts, band competitions, as well as [[soccer]] matches and other sporting events by partnering with the [[Central Alabama Sports Commission]]. ==See also== *[[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|New Alabama State Hornets football stadium}} * [http://bamastatesports.com/sports/2013/8/27/FB_0827131247.aspx?path=football New ASU Stadium website] {{Alabama State University}} {{Alabama State Hornets football navbox}} {{Southwestern Athletic Conference football venue navbox}} {{Alabama college football venues}} [[Category:Alabama State Hornets and Lady Hornets sports venues]] [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:American football venues in Alabama]] [[Category:Alabama State Hornets football]] [[Category:2012 establishments in Alabama]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2012]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Alabama]]

{{refimprove|date=October 2010}} '''Qods League (provinces)''' was a nine team football competition that existed in Iran for four years from 1985 to 1988. In 1989, the league became a competition between clubs rather than provinces.<ref>http://www.prosoccer.mihanblog.com/post/author/53557/page/5</ref>
==Teams== The 9 teams were: *[[Tehran|Tehran A]] *[[Tehran|Tehran B]] *[[Isfahan province|Esfehan]] *[[Gilan]] *[[Mazandaran]] *[[Khorasan Province|Khorasan]] *[[Fars Province|Fars]] *[[East Azerbaijan province|East Azerbaijan]] *[[Khuzestan]]
==Titles== ===1985=== This tournament was won by [[Tehran|Tehran A]].
===1986===
This tournament was won by [[Isfahan province|Esfehan]].
===1987===
This tournament was won by [[Isfahan province|Esfehan]].
===1988===
This tournament was won by [[Tehran|Tehran A]].
==See also== * [[Qods League]]

{{Infobox football club |clubname = Red Berets |image = [[Image:RedBeretsFC.png|100px|logo]] |fullname = Red Berets Football Club |nickname = Kenya Police |founded = 1980 |dissolved = 2011 |ground = [[Afraha Stadium]]
[[Nakuru]], [[Kenya]] |capacity = 8,200 |chairman = |manager = [[Caleb Okuku]] |season = 2010 |position = [[Kenyan Premier League]], 15th |pattern_la1= |pattern_b1= |pattern_ra1= |leftarm1=ff0000 |body1=ff0000 |rightarm1=ff0000 |shorts1=ffffff |socks1=ff0000 }} '''Red Berets Football Club''' was a [[Association football|football]] club based in [[Nakuru]], [[Kenya]]. It was based in [[Nairobi]] until 2007.[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/kenya07.html RSSSF – Kenya 2007] Its home ground was the [[Afraha Stadium]], but due to its unavailability in 2008, the club played its home games at the [[Greensteds School]] Grounds.[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/kenya08.html RSSSF – Kenya 2008] The club was founded in 1980 and owned by the [[Kenya Police]]. In 2000 it won promotion from the [[Kenyan Nationwide League|Nationwide League]] to the [[Kenyan Premier League|Premier League]], where it stayed until they were relegated at the end of the [[2010 Kenyan Premier League|2010 season]], after which it was disbanded as it was under immense pressure from its sponsors to produce good performances, contrary to the season they had.{{cite news |title=Red Berets FC disbanded |url=http://www.michezoafrika.com/Kpl/Red-Berets-FC-disbanded/896.aspx |author=Dennis Machio |publisher=MichezoAfrika.com |date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=17 May 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Kenyan Premier League plain}} [[Category:Football clubs in Kenya]] [[Category:Sport in Nairobi]] [[Category:Sport in Rift Valley Province]] [[Category:Nakuru]] [[Category:1980 establishments in Kenya]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1980]] [[Category:2011 disestablishments in Kenya]] [[Category:Association football clubs disestablished in 2011]] {{Kenya-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Rizal Memorial Coliseum | nickname = | image = RMSCjf9787 01.JPG | former names = Rizal Memorial Tennis Stadium | location = [[Manila]], [[Philippines]] | broke_ground = | opened = 1934 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Manila|City Government of Manila]] | operator = [[Philippine Sports Commission]] | architect = [[Juan Arellano]] | civil engineer = [[Pedro A. Siochi]] | surface = | construction_cost = | publictransit = {{rint|metro}} {{rint|manila|LRT-1}} {{lrt|Vito Cruz}} | tenants = [[Philippines women's national basketball team]]
[[Manila Industrial and Commercial Athletic Association|MICAA]] (1938–1981)
[[University Athletic Association of the Philippines|UAAP]] (1938–2002)
[[National Collegiate Athletic Association (Philippines)|NCAA]] (1938–1998, 2000–2004, 2006)
[[Philippine Basketball Association|PBA]] (1975–1977, 1980, 1982) | seating_capacity = |}} The '''Rizal Memorial Coliseum''' is one of two [[indoor arena|indoor sporting arenas]] located inside the [[Rizal Memorial Sports Complex]] in [[Manila]], [[Philippines]], the other being the [[Ninoy Aquino Stadium]]. The capacity of the coliseum is 8,000.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} The [[Art Deco architecture|Art Deco]] building within the Rizal Memorial Sports Complex was designed by [[Juan Arellano]] and was built in 1934 by the engineering firm of Pedro Siochi & Co., Inc.{{cite news|last1=Sembrano|first1=Edgar Allan|title=Erap plan to convert Rizal Coliseum into a mall scored|url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/245636/erap-plan-convert-rizal-coliseum-mall-scored/|accessdate=29 November 2016|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=28 November 2016}} The [[Philippine Sports Commission]] (PSC) unveiled plans for the conversion of the Rizal Memorial Coliseum into a Philippine Sports Museum and the Asian Games Museum which houses the memorabililia of Philippine and Asian sports icons and hall of famers. The current location of the PSM is located at the 2nd floor of the PSC building inside the Rizal Memorial Sports Complex. There was a plan to demolish the site before the PSC's announcement.{{cite news|url=http://balita.net.ph/2016/01/20/rizal-memorial-coliseum-gagawing-home-of-sports-hall-of-famers/|title=Rizal Memorial Coliseum, gagawing 'Home of Sports Hall of Famers'|trans-title=Rizal Memorial Coliseum will turned into a 'Home of Sports Hall of Famers'|language=Filipino|publisher=Balita|last=Oredo|first=Angie|date=20 January 2016|accessdate=20 January 2016}} On November 22, 2016, Manila Mayor [[Joseph Estrada]] announced that the city government is making a partnership with businessman Ricky Razon to convert the facility into a commercial center which will include a mall and cinemas.{{cite news|last1=Clapano|first1=Jose Rodel|title=Manila to turn Rizal coliseum into mall|url=http://www.philstar.com/metro/2016/11/23/1646558/manila-turn-rizal-coliseum-mall|accessdate=24 November 2016|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=23 November 2016}} The plan was criticized by the Heritage Conservation Society questioning if Manila needs another shopping mall. The [[National Commission for Culture and the Arts ]] also stated that the city government of Estrada never consulted the agency regarding their plans on the sports venue in particular despite promising to cooperate with the government body on [[cultural conservation]] in a meeting initiated by the Manila government on May 2016. == See also == *[[Rizal Memorial Sports Complex]] *[[Rizal Memorial Stadium]] *[[Rizal Memorial Baseball Stadium]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Commons category}} {{Sports venues in the Greater Manila Area}} {{coord|14|33|43|N|120|59|38|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Sports venues in Metro Manila]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in the Philippines]] [[Category:Basketball venues in the Philippines]] [[Category:Art Deco architecture in the Philippines]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Malate, Manila]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1934]] [[Category:1934 establishments in the Philippines]] {{Philippines-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=August 2016}}
'''Shoulder programming''' is a type of pre-event and post-event [[broadcast programming]] as a companion to [[broadcasting of sports events|live sporting events]]. This type of programming may be multi-platform and include both [[Television program|television]] and [[radio program]]s. Due to exclusive content or access, it may be included in a [[Sports broadcasting contracts in the United States|broadcast rights]] package for a particular sport or event. The purpose is to expand revenue opportunities through radio or [[television advertisement|television advertising]] or increased exposure to a [[pay-per-view]] event.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Deninger|first1=Dennis|title=Sports on Television: The how and why Behind what You See|date=2012|publisher=Routledge|pages=100–101|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MitTh_reHL8C|accessdate=28 February 2015|isbn=9780415896757}}</ref>
==Examples==
===NFL===
[[NFL Primetime]], [[Monday Night Countdown]], and ''SportsCenter Monday Kickoff'' have each been companion [[National Football League]] (NFL) programming for [[Monday Night Football]] on [[ESPN]]. Monday Night Football was highly rated on ABC from 1970 to 2005, but since ESPN took over in 2006, it could more directly surround the franchise with programming in the time-slots before and after the game.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Capon|first1=Noel|title=The Marketing Mavens|publisher=Crown Religion/Business/Forum|pages=128|url=https://books.google.com/?id=zZZB6PstbCkC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=28 February 2015|ref=2|isbn=9780307394477|date=2007-06-12}}</ref>
===UFC===
The first [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]] (UFC) event on [[UFC on Fox]] was [[UFC 121|UFC 121: Lesnar vs. Velasquez]] a title card between [[Junior dos Santos]] and [[Cain Velasquez]] in 2011. Networks such as [[Fox Deportes]], ''Fuel TV'' (since re-branded [[Fox Sports 2]] and [[Fox Sports Radio]] broadcast many hours of programming leading up to and during the fight. Programming included specials by both Fox Deportes and Fuel TV. Replays of the previously-held Velasquez vs Lesnar fight and the weigh-in were aired by Fox Deportes and Fuel TV, respectively. Live radio coverage of the fight was broadcast by Fox Sports Radio. Other programming included a UFC primetime special and the pre-fight and post-fight shows by Fuel TV.<ref>{{cite web|title=Plenty Of Shoulder Programming For UFC's Network Debut On Fox|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Closing-Bell/2011/11/11/Fox-UFC.aspx?hl=Octagon&sc=0|website=Sports Business Daily|accessdate=28 February 2015}}</ref>
==Criticism==
ESPN has been criticized for devoting more or less air-time to a sport depending on whether it has rights to the primary organization or league of that sport. Examples include less air-time for [[National Hockey League]] (NHL), including the cancellation of [[NHL 2Night]] following their expiration of ESPN's rights contract and expanding air-time for [[NASCAR]] and the [[Arena Football League]] following rights deals.<ref name="At ESPN, conflict of interest is business as usual">{{cite web|last1=Schreiber|first1=Le Anne|title=At ESPN, conflict of interest is business as usual|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/columns/story?id=2866241|website=ESPN|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=28 February 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

'''Strela-Agro'''<ref>http://rurugby.ru/competitions/russia15/1917-rugby-strela-agro</ref> ({{lang-ru|Стрела-Агро}}, formerly '''Agrouniversitet Kazan''') is a [[rugby union]] club based in [[Kazan]], [[Russia]].
They won the Russian second division in 2011. They participate in the [[Professional Rugby League|Russia Super League]] in 2012.

{{Infobox football club | nickname = | ground = [[Thika Municipal Stadium|Thika Sub-County Stadium]]
[[Thika]], [[Kenya]] | capacity = 5,000 | season = [[2018 Kenyan Premier League|2018]] | pattern_la1 = | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = |pattern_ra1= |pattern_ra2= | leftarm1 = 0000ff | leftarm2 = ffffff | body1 = 0000ff | body2 = ffffff | rightarm1 = 0000ff | rightarm2 = ffffff | shorts1 = 0000ff | shorts2 = ffffff |socks1=0000ff |socks2=ffffff | clubname = | fullname = Thika United Football Club | founded = 2000 | chairman = {{flagicon|KEN}} Elio Lolli | director = {{flagicon|KEN}} Michael Muriuki | mgrtitle = Head coach | manager = {{flagicon|KEN}} [[Nicholas Muyoti]] | league = [[Kenyan Premier League]] | position = 18th | pattern_b1 = |website = http://www.thikaunitedfc.com | image = }} '''Thika United Football Club''' is an [[association football]] club based in [[Thika]], [[Kenya]], which currently competes in the [[Kenya Super League]], the second tier of the [[Kenyan football league system]]. They play their home games at the Thika Sub-County Stadium. The club was formed in 2000 as ''Beirut FC''. The following year, after being promoted to the [[Nationwide League (Kenya)|Nationwide League]] (second level), it adopted new name, ''Medisca Thika'', after its then sponsors. The current name (Thika United FC) has been in use since 2003, which was also its first year in the top flight under the sponsorship of Brookside Dairies. Midfielder Matthew Dickinson hit the headlines of local and some national newspapers when he left local team Brislington Badgers in Bristol, England, to travel to Kenya to gain nationality and happened to earn himself a lengthy contract with Thika United. ==History== Thika United made their top flight debut in 2002 and finished third in 2006 and 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.nation.co.ke/lifestyle/sports/Thika-coach-hopes-patience-will-pay--/960656-1098210-13ikqxf/index.html|date=30 January 2011|title=Thika coach hopes patience will pay|last=Kitula|first=Sammy}} Thika United regained promotion to the [[Kenya Premier League]] after beating Ushuru F.C. 2-1 on aggregate in the 2017 Kenya Super League promotion playoffs.{{cite web|url=https://www.goal.com/en/news/thika-united-survive-kpl-promotion-battle/1g7ewsl26w7fp1ot7emjsqqmxv|title=Thika United survive KPL Promotion Battle|publisher=goal.com|date=24 December 2017}} They were relegated back to the Kenya Nationwide League after one season, finishing bottom of the [[Kenyan Premier League]] in 2018.{{cite web|url=https://au.soccerway.com/national/kenya/premier-league/2018/regular-season/r45235/|title=Summary -
